\title[One-relator pro-$p$ Galois groups and Koszul algebras]
 {One-relator maximal pro-$p$ Galois groups \\ and Koszul algebras}

\author{C. Quadrelli}

\dedicatory{To John P. Labute, with respect and admiration.}

\date{\today}
\address{Department of Mathematics \\ Ben-Gurion University of the Negev \\ P.O.B.~653\\ 84105 Be'er-Sheva, Israel}
\email{quadrell@math.bgu.ac.il}

\begin{abstract}
Let $p$ be a prime number and let $K$ be a field containing a root of 1 of order $p$.
If the maximal pro-$p$ Galois group $G_K(p)$ is a finitely generated one-relator pro-$p$ group,
we show that L.~Positselski's Koszulity conjecture is true for $K$.
Also, under the above hypothesis we show that the ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-cohomology ring of $G_K(p)$ is the quadratic dual
of a canonical graded algebra induced by the complete group algebra ${\mathbb{F}}_p{[\![} G_K(p){]\!]}$,
which decomposes as free product of quadratic algebras,
in analogy with a result by T.~W\"urfel on one-relator absolute pro-$p$ Galois groups.
\end{abstract}

\subjclass[2010]{Primary 12G05; Secondary 17A45,  20F40, 20F14}

\keywords{Galois cohomology, Koszulity conjecture, one-relator pro-$p$ groups, quadratic algebras, Demushkin groups}

\thanks{The author is supported by the Israel Science Fundation grant no. 152/13.}

\maketitle

\section{Introduction}

For a prime number $p$ and a field $K$, let $K(p)$ be the maximal $p$-extension of $K$ ---
namely, $K(p)$ is the compositum of all finite Galois $p$-extensions $L/K$.
The Galois group of $K(p)/K$, called the {\it maximal pro-$p$ Galois group} of $K$ and denoted by $G_K(p)$,
is the maximal pro-$p$ quotient of the absolute Galois group $G_K$ of $K$
(note that the class of maximal pro-$p$ Galois groups includes also absolute Galois groups which are pro-$p$).
Characterizing pro-$p$ groups which are realizable as maximal pro-$p$ Galois groups is one of the major problems
in current research in Galois theory.

A pro-$p$ group $G$ is said to be a {\it one-relator} pro-$p$ group if it has a minimal presentation 
with only one defining relation.
I.e., $G=F/R$, with $F$ a free pro-$p$ group (such that $G$ and $F$ have the same minimal number of generators)
and $R$ is generated as closed normal subgroup of $F$ by one element.
In \cite{wurf} T.~W\"urfel proved the following characterization for absolute Galois groups which are
one-relator pro-$p$ groups: if such $G_K$ is finitely generated and $K$ contains all the roots of unity
of order a $p$-power, then $G_K$ is a free-by-Demushkin group --- i.e., one may find a free pro-$p$ normal subgroup
$N$ of $G_K$ such that the quotient $G_K/N$ is a Demushkin group.
(Demushkin groups are Poincar\'e pro-$p$ groups of cohomological dimension two,
and they appear as maximal pro-$p$ Galois groups of certain local fields, see Section~\ref{ssec:demushkin}).

In order to obtain such result, W\"urfel used the Merkurjev-Suslin theorem (cf. \cite{ms}), which is
the ``degree-2 step'' of the well-known Bloch-Kato conjecture,
proved by M.~Rost and V.~Voevodsky (cf. \cite[Thm.~6.4.3]{nsw:cohm}).
In particular, the Bloch-Kato conjecture implies that if a field $K$ contains a root of unity of order $p$,
then the ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-cohomology ring $H^\bullet(G_K(p),{\mathbb{F}}_p)=\bigoplus_{n\geq0}H^n(G_K(p),{\mathbb{F}}_p)$,
endowed with the (graded-commutative) cup product

\end{theorem}

Demushkin algebras are one-relator (non-commutative) polynomial algebras related to Demushkin groups
(to be defined in Section~\ref{ssec:demushkin}).
In \cite{MQRTW} it is conjectured that the graded group algebra ${\rm gr}_\bullet({\mathbb{F}}_p{[\![} G_K(p){]\!]})$ is the quadratic dual 
of the ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-cohomology ring $H^\bullet(G_K(p),{\mathbb{F}}_p)$ for every field $K$ containing a root of unity of order $p$
such that $G_K(p)$ is finitely generated.
Thus, Theorem~\ref{thm2} provides new evidence to this conjecture.

Note that by \eqref{eq:obsA} and \eqref{eq:thmB} the two algebras $H^\bullet(G_K(p),{\mathbb{F}}_p)$
and ${\rm gr}_\bullet({\mathbb{F}}_p{[\![} G_K(p){]\!]})$ split in a ``Demushkin part'' and in a ``free part''.
In fact, we prove a generalization of W\"urfel's theorem to maximal pro-$p$ Galois groups ---
namely, under the assumptions of Theorem~\ref{thm2} the Galois group $G_K(p)$
is a free-by-Demushkin group (cf. Theorem~\ref{thm:wurfel} and Corollary~\ref{coro:wurfel}).

For a graded $\Bbbk$-algebra $A_\bullet$, one defines the $\Bbbk$-cohomology of $A_\bullet$ as the derived
functor of ${\mathrm{Hom}}_{A_\bullet}(\Bbbk,\Bbbk)$, which is endowed with an additional internal grading --- induced 
by the grading of $A_\bullet$ ---, so that one gets a bigraded algebra.
If the non-tivial cohomology groups are concentrated on the diagonal,
$A_\bullet$ is called a {\it Koszul $\Bbbk$-algebra} (cf. \cite{priddy}).
Koszul algebras arise in various fields of mathematics, such as representation theory, noncommutative algebra,
noncommutative geometry, algebraic geometry and topology, and they have been studied in
the context of Galois cohomology by L.~Positselski and A.~Vishik (cf. \cite{posivis:koszul}).
In particular, Positselski conjectured that if a field $K$ contains a root of unity of order $p$,
then the ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-cohomology ring of $G_K(p)$ is Koszul, and he showed that such conjecture is
a generalization of the Bloch-Kato conjecture (cf. \cite{positselsky:koszul1,positselsky:koszul2}).
From Observation~\ref{obs1} and Theorem~\ref{thm2} we obtain the following.

\begin{theorem}\label{thm3}
 Let $K$ be a field satisfying the assumptions of Theorem~\ref{thm2}.
Then the algebras $H^\bullet(G_K(p),{\mathbb{F}}_p)$ and ${\rm gr}_\bullet({\mathbb{F}}_p{[\![} G_K(p){]\!]})$ are Koszul.
\end{theorem}

In particular, Theorem~\ref{thm3} provides new evidence to Positselski's conjecture.

Finally, we observe that there are finitely generated free-by-Demushkin pro-$p$ groups for which
the results of the present paper do hold, but which are not realizable
as maximal pro-$p$ Galois groups of fields (cf. Example~\ref{ex:KZ}).
We ask whether one may find further conditions that the defining relation of such pro-$p$ groups
should satisfy to make them Galois --- or obstructions which prevent them to be maximal pro-$p$ Galois groups.

Thus, we may consider $\Omega^\perp$ as a subspace of $A_1^*\otimes A_1^*$.
The {\it quadratic dual} of $A_\bullet$, denoted by $A_\bullet^!$, is the quadratic $\Bbbk$-algebra
obtained via the quotient $T_\bullet(A_1^*)/\langle \Omega^\perp\rangle$.
\end{itemize}
\end{definition}

In particular, for a quadratic $\Bbbk$-algebra $A_\bullet$ one has $(A_\bullet^!)^!=A_\bullet$.
Moreover, one has the following (cf. \cite[Prop.~1.3.1 and Definition~2.1]{PoliPosi}).

\begin{proposition}\label{prop:koszul}
let $A_\bullet$ be a graded $\Bbbk$-algebra.
\begin{itemize}
 \item[(i)] The diagonal of $H^\bullet(A_\bullet)$ is isomorphic to the quadratic dual of $\mathrm{q}A_\bullet$,
i.e., one has an isomorphism $\bigoplus_{i\geq0}{\mathrm{Ext}}_{A_\bullet}^{i,i}(\Bbbk,\Bbbk)\simeq(\mathrm{q}A_\bullet)^!$.
 \item[(ii)] If $A_\bullet$ is Koszul, then it is quadratic.
\end{itemize}
\end{proposition}

The above proposition implies that a quadratic $\Bbbk$-algebra $A_\bullet$
is Koszul if, and only if, one has $H^\bullet(A_\bullet)\simeq A_\bullet^!$.
Moreover, a quadratic $\Bbbk$-algebra $A_\bullet$ is Koszul if, and only if, the quadratic dual 
$A_\bullet^!$ is Koszul (cf. \cite[Prop.~3.4.8]{lodval}).
For further details on Koszul algebras we refer to \cite[Ch.~2]{PoliPosi}.

One has the following examples of Koszul $\Bbbk$-algebras (cf. \cite[Ex.s~3.2.5 and Ex.s~3.4.12]{lodval}).

\begin{example}\label{exs:quadratic}
Let $V$ be a vector space of finite dimension over $\Bbbk$.
 \begin{itemize}
  \item[(a)] The tensor $\Bbbk$-algebra $T_\bullet(V)$ and the trivial quadratic $\Bbbk$-algebra $\Bbbk\oplus V$
(with $V$ the part of degree 1) are Koszul algebras, and $T_\bullet(V)^!={\mathbb{F}}_p\oplus V^*$ and conversely.
  \item[(b)] The symmetric algebra $S^\bullet(V)$ and the exterior algebra $\Lambda_\bullet(V)$
are Koszul algebras, and $S^\bullet(V)^!=\Lambda_\bullet(V^*)$ and conversely.
 \end{itemize}
\end{example}

Given two quadratic $\Bbbk$-algebras $A_\bullet$ and $B_\bullet$, the direct product and the free product
of $A_\bullet$ and $B_\bullet$ are defined in the following way.
\begin{itemize}
 \item[(a)] The direct product of $A_\bullet$ and $B_\bullet$ is the quadratic ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra
$C_\bullet=A_\bullet\sqcap B_\bullet$ with $C_n=A_n\oplus B_n$ for every $n\geq1$.
 \item[(b)] The free product of $A_\bullet$ and $B_\bullet$ is the quadratic ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra
$C_\bullet=A_\bullet\sqcup B_\bullet$ with $C_1=A_1\oplus B_1$ and 
$C_2=A_2\oplus B_2\oplus(A_1\otimes B_1)\oplus(B_1\otimes A_1)$.
\end{itemize}

For such algebras one has the following (cf. \cite[\S~3.1]{PoliPosi}).

\begin{proposition}\label{prop:products}
 Let $A_\bullet$ and $B_\bullet$ be quadratic $\Bbbk$-algebras.
If both $A_\bullet$ and $B_\bullet$ are Koszul algebras, then also the direct product $A_\bullet\sqcap B_\bullet$
and the free product $A_\bullet\sqcup B_\bullet$ are Koszul algebras.

\subsection{Demushkin algebras}
\label{ssec:demushkin}

For a vector space $V$ over $\Bbbk$ of finite dimension $d$, let $ X =\{X_1,\ldots,X_d\}$ be
a set of (non-commutative) indeterminates.
The free associative algebra $\Bbbk\langle X\rangle$ --- i.e., the $\Bbbk$-algebra of polynomials on the
non commutative indeterminates $X$ --- comes endowed with the grading induced
by the subspaces of homogeneous polynomials.
We may identify $ X $ with a fixed basis of $V$, and such identification induces an isomorphism
of quadratic $\Bbbk$-algebras $T_\bullet(V)\simeq\Bbbk\langle X\rangle$.

\begin{lemma}\label{lemma:onerel koszul}
 Let $f\in\Bbbk\langle X\rangle$ be a homogeneous polynomial of degree 2 such that 
$f\neq X_1^{2\delta_1}+\ldots+X_d^{2\delta_d}$, with $\delta_i\in\{0,1\}$ for every $i=1,\ldots,d$
--- i.e., $f$ contains a monomial $\alpha X_iX_j$ with $\alpha\in\Bbbk\smallsetminus\{0\}$ and $i\neq j$.
Then the quadratic $\Bbbk$-algebra $\Bbbk\langle X\rangle/\langle f\rangle$ is Koszul.
\end{lemma}

\begin{proof}
 Up to renumbering of $X$ we may assume that $f$ contains the monomial $X_dX_{d-1}$.
For every $n\geq1$ let the monomial basis ${\mathcal{S}}_n=\{X_{i_1}\cdots X_{i_n},1\leq i_1,\ldots,i_n\leq d\}$
be endowed with the lexicographic ordering $\prec$.
Then $(\bigcup_n{\mathcal{S}}_n,\prec)$ is a totally ordered set.
In particular, we may write the relation $f=0$ as

\end{definition}

In particular, for a quadratic $\Bbbk$-algebra $A_\bullet$ one has $(A_\bullet^!)^!=A_\bullet$.
Moreover, one has the following (cf. \cite[Prop.~1.3.1 and Definition~2.1]{PoliPosi}).

\begin{proposition}\label{prop:koszul}
let $A_\bullet$ be a graded $\Bbbk$-algebra.
\begin{itemize}
 \item[(i)] The diagonal of $H^\bullet(A_\bullet)$ is isomorphic to the quadratic dual of $\mathrm{q}A_\bullet$,
i.e., one has an isomorphism $\bigoplus_{i\geq0}{\mathrm{Ext}}_{A_\bullet}^{i,i}(\Bbbk,\Bbbk)\simeq(\mathrm{q}A_\bullet)^!$.
 \item[(ii)] If $A_\bullet$ is Koszul, then it is quadratic.
\end{itemize}
\end{proposition}

The above proposition implies that a quadratic $\Bbbk$-algebra $A_\bullet$
is Koszul if, and only if, one has $H^\bullet(A_\bullet)\simeq A_\bullet^!$.
Moreover, a quadratic $\Bbbk$-algebra $A_\bullet$ is Koszul if, and only if, the quadratic dual 
$A_\bullet^!$ is Koszul (cf. \cite[Prop.~3.4.8]{lodval}).
For further details on Koszul algebras we refer to \cite[Ch.~2]{PoliPosi}.

One has the following examples of Koszul $\Bbbk$-algebras (cf. \cite[Ex.s~3.2.5 and Ex.s~3.4.12]{lodval}).

\begin{example}\label{exs:quadratic}
Let $V$ be a vector space of finite dimension over $\Bbbk$.
 \begin{itemize}
  \item[(a)] The tensor $\Bbbk$-algebra $T_\bullet(V)$ and the trivial quadratic $\Bbbk$-algebra $\Bbbk\oplus V$
(with $V$ the part of degree 1) are Koszul algebras, and $T_\bullet(V)^!={\mathbb{F}}_p\oplus V^*$ and conversely.
  \item[(b)] The symmetric algebra $S^\bullet(V)$ and the exterior algebra $\Lambda_\bullet(V)$
are Koszul algebras, and $S^\bullet(V)^!=\Lambda_\bullet(V^*)$ and conversely.
 \end{itemize}
\end{example}

$C_2=A_2\oplus B_2\oplus(A_1\otimes B_1)\oplus(B_1\otimes A_1)$.
\end{itemize}

In a quadratic $\Bbbk$-algebra $A_\bullet=\Bbbk\langle X\rangle/\langle \Omega\rangle$, 
with $\Omega$ a set of homogeneous polynomials of degree 2,
a monomial $h=X_{i_1}X_{i_2}X_{i_3}\in{\mathcal{S}}_3$ is said to be {\it critical}
if both $X_{i_1}X_{i_2}$ and $X_{i_2}X_{i_3}$ are leading terms (with respect to $\prec$) of some relations in Omega
(c.f. \cite[\S~4.1]{lodval}) --- i.e., the monomial $h$ may be rewritten in $A_\bullet$ using lower monomials
with respect to $\prec$ in at least two ways, which may eventually lead to different results.
 
The $\Bbbk$-algebra $\Bbbk\langle X\rangle/\langle f\rangle$ has no critical monomials, as one can not have
$X_{i_1}X_{i_2}=X_{i_2}X_{i_3}=X_dX_{d-1}$ for any $i_1,i_2,i_3\in\{1,\ldots,d\}$,
and no monomials can be rewritten using lower monomials.
By \cite[Thm.~4.1.1]{lodval}, quadratic $\Bbbk$-algebras without critical monomials are Koszul,
and so is $\Bbbk\langle X\rangle/\langle f\rangle$.
\end{proof}

Demushkin groups are one-relator pro-$p$ groups, and their structure was fully described by S.P.~Demushkin,
J.-P.~Serre and J.P.~Labute (cf. \cite[\S~III.9]{nsw:cohm}).
Moreover, they appear in Galois theory as the maximal pro-$p$ Galois groups of certain $p$-adic local fields
(cf. \cite[Thm.~7.5.11]{nsw:cohm}).

\begin{definition}\label{defi:demushkin}
A {\it Demushkin ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra} $D_\bullet$ is a quadratic ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra such that its diagonal
${\mathbb{F}}_p$-cohomology is isomorphic to the ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-cohomology ring of a Demushkin group. 
I.e., ${\mathrm{Ext}}_{D_\bullet}^{1,1}\simeq D_1$,
${\mathrm{Ext}}_{D_\bullet}^{2,2}({\mathbb{F}}_p,{\mathbb{F}}_p)\simeq{\mathbb{F}}_p$ and the cup product induces a non-degenerate ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-pairing 
${\mathrm{Ext}}_{D_\bullet}^{1,1}({\mathbb{F}}_p,{\mathbb{F}}_p)\times{\mathrm{Ext}}_{D_\bullet}^{1,1}({\mathbb{F}}_p,{\mathbb{F}}_p)\to {\mathbb{F}}_p$.
 \end{definition}

By Proposition~\ref{prop:koszul} the diagonal cohomology of a Demushkin ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra is a 
quadratic ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra $A_\bullet$ with $\dim(A_1)=\dim(D_1)=d$, with $d$ even if $p$ is odd.
In particular, there is a basis $\{a_1\,\ldots,a_d\}$ of $A_1$ such that

\begin{definition}\label{defi:grG and zassenhaus}

$G_{(n)}=\{g\in G\mid g-1\in I^n\}$ for every $n\geq1$.
\end{definition}

\begin{remark}\label{rem:free1}
 Let $F$ be a finitely generated pro-$p$ group, and let $\{x_1,\ldots,x_d\}$ be a minimal set of generators for $F$.
Moreover, let ${\mathbb{F}}_p{\langle\!\langle} X{\rangle\!\rangle}$ be the ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra of formal power series on the set of indeterminates $X=\{X_1,\ldots,X_d\}$.
Then one has an isomorphism of (topological) ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebras ${\mathbb{F}}_p{[\![} F{]\!]}\simeq{\mathbb{F}}_p{\langle\!\langle} X{\rangle\!\rangle}$,
called the {\it Magnus morphism}, given by $x_i\mapsto 1+X_i$ for every $i=1,\ldots,d$.
The Magnus morphism maps the augmentation ideal of ${\mathbb{F}}_p{[\![} F{]\!]}$ onto the two-sided ideal

Thus, we may identify the graded algebra ${\rm gr}_\bullet({\mathbb{F}}_p{\langle\!\langle} X{\rangle\!\rangle})=\bigoplus_{n\geq0}I(X)^n/I(X)^{n+1}$, with $I(X)^0={\mathbb{F}}_p{\langle\!\langle} X{\rangle\!\rangle}$,
with the free polynomial algebra ${{\mathbb{F}}_p\langle X\rangle}$, endowed with the grading induced by the subspaces of homogeneous polynomials.
Also, via this identification one has $F_{(n)}=\{g\in F\mid g-1\in I(X)^n\}$ for every $n\geq1$.
\end{remark}



\subsection{Pro-$p$ groups and restricted Lie algebras}
\label{ssec:restricted}

Given an associative ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra $R$, let $R_L$ denote the Lie ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra endowed with the Lie brackets
$(a,b)=ab-ba$ for every $a,b\in R$.
One has the following definition (cf. \cite[\S~12.1]{ddsms:analytic}).

\begin{definition}\label{defi:restricted}
\begin{itemize}
 \item[(i)] A {\it restricted} Lie ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra $L$ over ${\mathbb{F}}_p$ is a Lie ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra equipped with
a $p$-power map $[p]\colon L\longrightarrow L$ which is compatible with the Lie brackets.
I.e., there exists an associative ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra $R$ and a monomorphism of Lie algebras
$\theta\colon L\to R_L$ such that $\theta(v^{[p]})=\theta(v)^p$ for all $v\in L$.
 \item[(ii)] The algebra $R$, endowed with the monomorphism $\theta\colon L\to R_L$, is called the
{\it universal restricted envelope} of $L$ if for any morphism of restricted Lie algebras $\varphi\colon L\to B_L$,
with $B$ an associative ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra, there exists a unique homomorphism of associative ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebras
$\tilde\varphi\colon R\to B$ such that $\varphi=\tilde\varphi\circ\theta$.
\end{itemize}
\end{definition}

We shall denote the universal restricted envelope of a restricted Lie ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra $L$ by ${\mathcal U}(L)$.
A restricted ideal $\mathfrak{r}$ of a restricted Lie ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra is an ideal in the classic sense
with the further condition that $v^{[p]}\in\mathfrak{r}$ for every $v\in\mathfrak{r}$.
Then one has the following (cf. \cite[Prop.~2.1]{jochen:massey})

\begin{proposition}\label{prop:presentation U}
Let $L$ be a restricted Lie algebra over ${\mathbb{F}}_p$ and let $\mathfrak{r}\subseteq L$ be a restricted ideal.
Let $\mathcal{R}$ be the left ideal of ${\mathcal U}(L)$ generated by the image of $\mathfrak{r}$
via the embedding $\theta\colon L\to{\mathcal U}(L)$.
Then $\mathcal{R}$ is a two-sided ideal and the epimorphism $L\to L/\mathfrak{r}$ induces a short exact sequence

\subsection{Pro-$p$ groups and restricted Lie algebras}
\label{ssec:restricted}

Given an associative ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra $R$, let $R_L$ denote the Lie ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra endowed with the Lie brackets
$(a,b)=ab-ba$ for every $a,b\in R$.
One has the following definition (cf. \cite[\S~12.1]{ddsms:analytic}).

\begin{definition}\label{defi:restricted}
\begin{itemize}
 \item[(i)] A {\it restricted} Lie ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra $L$ over ${\mathbb{F}}_p$ is a Lie ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra equipped with
a $p$-power map $[p]\colon L\longrightarrow L$ which is compatible with the Lie brackets.
I.e., there exists an associative ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra $R$ and a monomorphism of Lie algebras
$\theta\colon L\to R_L$ such that $\theta(v^{[p]})=\theta(v)^p$ for all $v\in L$.
 \item[(ii)] The algebra $R$, endowed with the monomorphism $\theta\colon L\to R_L$, is called the
{\it universal restricted envelope} of $L$ if for any morphism of restricted Lie algebras $\varphi\colon L\to B_L$,
with $B$ an associative ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra, there exists a unique homomorphism of associative ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebras
$\tilde\varphi\colon R\to B$ such that $\varphi=\tilde\varphi\circ\theta$.
\end{itemize}
\end{definition}

We shall denote the universal restricted envelope of a restricted Lie ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra $L$ by ${\mathcal U}(L)$.
A restricted ideal $\mathfrak{r}$ of a restricted Lie ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra is an ideal in the classic sense
with the further condition that $v^{[p]}\in\mathfrak{r}$ for every $v\in\mathfrak{r}$.
Then one has the following (cf. \cite[Prop.~2.1]{jochen:massey})

\begin{proposition}\label{prop:presentation U}
Let $L$ be a restricted Lie algebra over ${\mathbb{F}}_p$ and let $\mathfrak{r}\subseteq L$ be a restricted ideal.
Let $\mathcal{R}$ be the left ideal of ${\mathcal U}(L)$ generated by the image of $\mathfrak{r}$
via the embedding $\theta\colon L\to{\mathcal U}(L)$.
Then $\mathcal{R}$ is a two-sided ideal and the epimorphism $L\to L/\mathfrak{r}$ induces a short exact sequence

By \eqref{eq:properties Zassenhaus} every quotient $G_{(n)}/G_{(n+1)}$ is a ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-vector space, and 
the commutators and the $p$-power induce the structure of graded restricted Lie algebra on $L(G)$.
Moreover, the universal restricted envelope of $L(G)$ is the graded ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra ${\rm gr}_\bullet({\mathbb{F}}_p{[\![} G{]\!]})$
(cf. \cite[Thm.~12.8]{ddsms:analytic}).
If $g\in G_{(n)}\smallsetminus G_{(n+1)}$, $n\geq1$, we shall call the image of $g$ in $G_{(n)}/G_{(n+1)}$
the {\it initial form} of $g$ in $L(G)$.

\begin{remark}\label{rem:free2}
If $F$ is a finitely generated free pro-$p$ group, with minimal generating set $\{x_1,\ldots,x_d\}$,
we may identify the universal restricted envelope ${\mathcal U}(L(F))$ --- and therefore the graded group algebra
${\rm gr}_\bullet({\mathbb{F}}_p{[\![} F{]\!]})$ --- with the free polynomial algebra ${{\mathbb{F}}_p\langle X\rangle}$, with $X=\{X_1,\ldots,X_d\}$.
In particular, the restricted Lie ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra $L(F)$ is the free restricted Lie ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra on $X$
(cf. \cite[Remark~2.3]{jochen:massey}).
\end{remark}

Let $G=F/R$ be a finitely generated pro-$p$ group, with $R$ a normal subgroup of $F$.
Then the restricted Lie ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra $L(G)$ is a quotient $L(F)/\mathfrak{r}$, with $\mathfrak{r}$
a restricted ideal of $L(F)$, and thus by Proposition~\ref{prop:presentation U} the graded ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra
${\rm gr}_\bullet({\mathbb{F}}_p{[\![} G{]\!]})$ is isomorphic to a quotient ${{\mathbb{F}}_p\langle X\rangle}/\mathcal{R}$, with $\mathcal{R}$ the two-sided
ideal of ${{\mathbb{F}}_p\langle X\rangle}$ generated by $\mathfrak{r}$.

Moreover, such a pro-$p$ group $G$ is called {\it mild} (with respect to the Zassenhaus filtration)
if there is a minimal set of defining relations $\{r_1,\ldots,r_m\}$ (i.e., a minimal subset of $F$ 
which generates $R$ as normal subgroup of $F$) which is a {\it strongly free} sequence (with respect
to the Zassenhaus filtration), see \cite[Definition~2.7 and Definition~2.11]{jochen:massey}.
Mild pro-$p$ groups were introduced by J.~Labute in \cite{labute:mild}.
The feature of mild pro-$p$ groups we are interested in is the following:
if a pro-$p$ group $G$ is mild, then $L(G)=L(F)/\mathfrak{r}$, whith $\mathfrak{r}$ the restricted ideal
of $L(F)$ generated by the initial forms of the relations $r_i$ (cf. \cite[Thm.~2.12]{jochen:massey}).

and $R$ generated as normal subgroup of $F$ by an element $r\in F$, which is called the defining relation.
In particular, one has $r\in F_{(2)}$, as the presentation is minimal, and $H^2(G)\simeq{\mathbb{F}}_p$,
as the $\dim(H^2(G))$ is the minimal number of generators of $R$ as normal subgroup of $F$
(cf. \cite[\S~III.9]{nsw:cohm}).

\begin{lemma}\label{lemma:onerel}
 Let $G=F/R$ be a finitely generated one-relator pro-$p$ group, with defining relation $r$.
Assume that $r\notin F_{(3)}$, and if $p=2$ assume further that $r\notin F^2$.
Then $G$ is mild, and the ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-cohomology ring $H^\bullet(G)$ is quadratic.
\end{lemma}

\begin{proof}
Identify the graded group algebra ${\rm gr}_\bullet({\mathbb{F}}_p{[\![} F{]\!]})$ with the algebra ${{\mathbb{F}}_p\langle X\rangle}$, with $X=\{X_1,\ldots,X_d\}$.
Thus, the initial form $\rho$ of $r$ is a homogeneous polynomial of degree two.

Let $\{x_1,\ldots,x_d\}\subseteq F$ be a minimal generating set for $F$.
By hypothesis, there are $x_i\neq x_j$ such that the commutator $[x_i,x_j]$ appears in $r$.
Up to renumbering, we may assume $i=d-1$ and $j=d$.
Therefore, the monomial $\alpha X_dX_{d-1}$, with $\alpha\in{\mathbb{F}}_p$, is the leading monomial of $\rho$,
and the sequence $\{X_nX_{n-1}\}$ is combinatorially free in the sense of \cite[Definition~3.1]{jochen:massey}.
Hence, by \cite[Thm.~3.5]{jochen:massey} the sequence $\{\rho\}\subseteq{{\mathbb{F}}_p\langle X\rangle}$ is strongly free, and $G$ is a mild.
(See also \cite[Cor.~5.10]{jochen:massey}.)

Moreover, by \cite[Prop.~3.9.13]{nsw:cohm} the one has $\chi_{d-1}\cup\chi_d\neq0$. 
Thus, $\chi_{d-1}\cup\chi_d$ generates $H^2(G)\simeq{\mathbb{F}}_p$, and $H^n(G)=0$ for $n>2$ by \cite[Thm.~2.12-(i)]{jochen:massey}.
Therefore, $H^\bullet(G)$ is a quadratic ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra.
\end{proof}

Henceforth, we shall assume that the ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-cohomology ring $H^\bullet(G)$ is quadratic.

\section{Main results}
\label{sec:main}

\subsection{Maximal pro-$p$ Galois groups}
\label{ssec:proofs}

Assume that the maximal pro-$p$ Galois group $G=G_K(p)$ of a field $K$ is a finitely generated one-relator pro-$p$ group.
Note that $G$ is finitely generated if, and only if, the quotient $K^\times/(K^\times)^p$ of the multiplicative group
$K^\times=K\smallsetminus\{0\}$ is finite, as one has the (Pontryagin) duality 
$K^\times/(K^\times)^p= (G/G_{(2)})^*$.

A pro-$p$ group $G$ is called a {\it Bloch-Kato pro-$p$ group} if the ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-cohomology ring $H^\bullet(C)$
is a quadratic ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra for every closed subgroup $C$ of $G$. 
If $K$ contains a root of unity of order $p$, the Galois group $G_K(p)$
is a Bloch-Kato pro-$p$ group by the Rost-Voevodsky Theorem (cf. \cite[\S~2]{cq:bk}),
so that the ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-cohomology ring of the Galois group $G_K(p)$ is quadratic.

Observation~\ref{obs1} follows directly by Proposition~\ref{prop:case1 cohomology}
and Proposition~\ref{prop:case2 cohomology} (and by Remark~\ref{rem:p2}) in the case $p=q=2$ and $n=1$).

\begin{proof}[Proof of Theorem~\ref{thm2} and Theorem~\ref{thm3}]
Set $d=\dim(H^1(G_K(p)))$, and let $q$, and $n,m$ be as in Section~\ref{sec:onerel}.

Assume first that $p=q=2$ and $n=1$.
By \eqref{eq:grad n1} the graded group algebra ${\rm gr}_\bullet({\mathbb{F}}_p{[\![} G_K(p){]\!]})$ splits as free product
of a trivial quadratic ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra (on one generator) and a free associative graded ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra
(on $m$ generators).
The former is a Demushkin ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra by Proposition~\ref{prop:demushkin shape}, and \eqref{eq:thmB} holds.
Moreover, by \eqref{eq:cohom n1} the ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-cohomology ring $H^\bullet(G_K(p))$ decomposes as direct product of the free ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra
on $V_1\simeq{\mathbb{F}}_p$ and the trivial quadratic ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra on $V_2$.
By Example~\ref{exs:quadratic} such algebras are quadratic dual respectively to the ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebras in \eqref{eq:grad n1},
and thus $H^\bullet(G_K(p))$ is dual to ${\rm gr}_\bullet({\mathbb{F}}_p{[\![} G_K(p){]\!]})$ by Proposition~\ref{prop:products}.
This establishes Theorem~\ref{thm2} in this case.
Finally, by Example~\ref{exs:quadratic} all the algebras appearing in \eqref{eq:grad n1} and \eqref{eq:cohom n1}
are Koszul, thus both ${\rm gr}_\bullet({\mathbb{F}}_p{[\![} G_K(p){]\!]})$ and $H^\bullet(G_K(p))$ are Koszul by Proposition~\ref{prop:products},
and this proves Theorem~\ref{thm3} in this case.

Assume now that $p$ is odd, or $p=2$ and $q\neq2$, so that we are in the first case.
The isomorphism \eqref{eq:case1 algebra} yields \eqref{eq:thmB}.
Moreover, by Lemma~\ref{lemma:demushkin dual} the Demushkin ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra $D_\bullet$ in \eqref{eq:case1 algebra}
is quadratic dual to the algebra $A_\bullet$ in \eqref{eq:case1 cohomology}, and by Example~\ref{exs:quadratic}
the free ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra in \eqref{eq:case1 algebra} is quadratic dual to
the trivial quadratic ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra $B_\bullet$ in \eqref{eq:case1 cohomology},
so that ${\rm gr}_\bullet({\mathbb{F}}_p{[\![} G_K(p){]\!]})$ is dual to $H^\bullet(G_K(p))$ by Proposition~\ref{prop:products}.
This establishes Theorem~\ref{thm2} in this case.
Finally, by Example~\ref{exs:quadratic} and Proposition~\ref{prop:demushkin algebra koszul} all such algebras
are Koszul, and Proposition~\ref{prop:products} yields Theorem~\ref{thm3} in this case.

At last, assume that $p=q=2$ and $n>1$.
The isomorphism \eqref{eq:case2 algebra} yields \eqref{eq:thmB}.
Moreover, by Lemma~\ref{lemma:demushkin dual} the Demushkin ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra $D_\bullet$ in \eqref{eq:case2 algebra}
is quadratic dual to the algebra $A_\bullet$ in \eqref{eq:case2 cohomology}, and by Example~\ref{exs:quadratic}
the free ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra in \eqref{eq:case2 algebra} is quadratic dual to
the trivial quadratic ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra $B_\bullet$ in \eqref{eq:case2 cohomology},
so that ${\rm gr}_\bullet({\mathbb{F}}_p{[\![} G_K(p){]\!]})$ is dual to $H^\bullet(G_K(p))$ by Proposition~\ref{prop:products}.
This establishes Theorem~\ref{thm2} in this case.
Finally, by Example~\ref{exs:quadratic} and Proposition~\ref{prop:demushkin algebra koszul} all such algebras
are Koszul, and Proposition~\ref{prop:products} yields Theorem~\ref{thm3} in this case.
\end{proof}

Moreover, it is possible to generalize W\"urfel's theorem to Bloch-Kato pro-$p$ groups (and therefore in particular
to maximal pro-$p$ Galois groups of fields) as follows.

\begin{theorem}\label{thm:wurfel}
 Let $G$ be a finitely generated one-relator Bloch-Kato pro-$p$ group.
Then $G$ is a free-by-Demushkin group. 
In particular, if $K$ is a field contining a root of unity of order $p$,
and $G_K(p)$ is a finitely generated one-relator pro-$p$ group, then $G_K(p)$ is a free-by-Demushkin group. 
\end{theorem}

induces an isomorphism $H^1(G)^\perp\simeq H^1(C)$.
In particular, one has ${\mathrm{ker}}({\rm res}_{G,C}^1)=V_1$.
Therefore, the commutative diagram

\section{Main results}
\label{sec:main}

\subsection{Maximal pro-$p$ Galois groups}
\label{ssec:proofs}

Assume that the maximal pro-$p$ Galois group $G=G_K(p)$ of a field $K$ is a finitely generated one-relator pro-$p$ group.
Note that $G$ is finitely generated if, and only if, the quotient $K^\times/(K^\times)^p$ of the multiplicative group
$K^\times=K\smallsetminus\{0\}$ is finite, as one has the (Pontryagin) duality 
$K^\times/(K^\times)^p= (G/G_{(2)})^*$.

A pro-$p$ group $G$ is called a {\it Bloch-Kato pro-$p$ group} if the ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-cohomology ring $H^\bullet(C)$
is a quadratic ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra for every closed subgroup $C$ of $G$. 
If $K$ contains a root of unity of order $p$, the Galois group $G_K(p)$
is a Bloch-Kato pro-$p$ group by the Rost-Voevodsky Theorem (cf. \cite[\S~2]{cq:bk}),
so that the ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-cohomology ring of the Galois group $G_K(p)$ is quadratic.

Observation~\ref{obs1} follows directly by Proposition~\ref{prop:case1 cohomology}
and Proposition~\ref{prop:case2 cohomology} (and by Remark~\ref{rem:p2}) in the case $p=q=2$ and $n=1$).

\begin{proof}[Proof of Theorem~\ref{thm2} and Theorem~\ref{thm3}]
Set $d=\dim(H^1(G_K(p)))$, and let $q$, and $n,m$ be as in Section~\ref{sec:onerel}.

Assume first that $p=q=2$ and $n=1$.
By \eqref{eq:grad n1} the graded group algebra ${\rm gr}_\bullet({\mathbb{F}}_p{[\![} G_K(p){]\!]})$ splits as free product
of a trivial quadratic ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra (on one generator) and a free associative graded ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra
(on $m$ generators).
The former is a Demushkin ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra by Proposition~\ref{prop:demushkin shape}, and \eqref{eq:thmB} holds.
Moreover, by \eqref{eq:cohom n1} the ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-cohomology ring $H^\bullet(G_K(p))$ decomposes as direct product of the free ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra
on $V_1\simeq{\mathbb{F}}_p$ and the trivial quadratic ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra on $V_2$.
By Example~\ref{exs:quadratic} such algebras are quadratic dual respectively to the ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebras in \eqref{eq:grad n1},
and thus $H^\bullet(G_K(p))$ is dual to ${\rm gr}_\bullet({\mathbb{F}}_p{[\![} G_K(p){]\!]})$ by Proposition~\ref{prop:products}.
This establishes Theorem~\ref{thm2} in this case.
Finally, by Example~\ref{exs:quadratic} all the algebras appearing in \eqref{eq:grad n1} and \eqref{eq:cohom n1}
are Koszul, thus both ${\rm gr}_\bullet({\mathbb{F}}_p{[\![} G_K(p){]\!]})$ and $H^\bullet(G_K(p))$ are Koszul by Proposition~\ref{prop:products},
and this proves Theorem~\ref{thm3} in this case.

Assume now that $p$ is odd, or $p=2$ and $q\neq2$, so that we are in the first case.
The isomorphism \eqref{eq:case1 algebra} yields \eqref{eq:thmB}.
Moreover, by Lemma~\ref{lemma:demushkin dual} the Demushkin ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra $D_\bullet$ in \eqref{eq:case1 algebra}
is quadratic dual to the algebra $A_\bullet$ in \eqref{eq:case1 cohomology}, and by Example~\ref{exs:quadratic}
the free ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra in \eqref{eq:case1 algebra} is quadratic dual to
the trivial quadratic ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra $B_\bullet$ in \eqref{eq:case1 cohomology},
so that ${\rm gr}_\bullet({\mathbb{F}}_p{[\![} G_K(p){]\!]})$ is dual to $H^\bullet(G_K(p))$ by Proposition~\ref{prop:products}.
This establishes Theorem~\ref{thm2} in this case.
Finally, by Example~\ref{exs:quadratic} and Proposition~\ref{prop:demushkin algebra koszul} all such algebras
are Koszul, and Proposition~\ref{prop:products} yields Theorem~\ref{thm3} in this case.

At last, assume that $p=q=2$ and $n>1$.
The isomorphism \eqref{eq:case2 algebra} yields \eqref{eq:thmB}.
Moreover, by Lemma~\ref{lemma:demushkin dual} the Demushkin ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra $D_\bullet$ in \eqref{eq:case2 algebra}
is quadratic dual to the algebra $A_\bullet$ in \eqref{eq:case2 cohomology}, and by Example~\ref{exs:quadratic}
the free ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra in \eqref{eq:case2 algebra} is quadratic dual to
the trivial quadratic ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra $B_\bullet$ in \eqref{eq:case2 cohomology},
so that ${\rm gr}_\bullet({\mathbb{F}}_p{[\![} G_K(p){]\!]})$ is dual to $H^\bullet(G_K(p))$ by Proposition~\ref{prop:products}.
This establishes Theorem~\ref{thm2} in this case.
Finally, by Example~\ref{exs:quadratic} and Proposition~\ref{prop:demushkin algebra koszul} all such algebras
are Koszul, and Proposition~\ref{prop:products} yields Theorem~\ref{thm3} in this case.
\end{proof}

Moreover, it is possible to generalize W\"urfel's theorem to Bloch-Kato pro-$p$ groups (and therefore in particular
to maximal pro-$p$ Galois groups of fields) as follows.

\begin{theorem}\label{thm:wurfel}
 Let $G$ be a finitely generated one-relator Bloch-Kato pro-$p$ group.
Then $G$ is a free-by-Demushkin group. 
In particular, if $K$ is a field contining a root of unity of order $p$,
and $G_K(p)$ is a finitely generated one-relator pro-$p$ group, then $G_K(p)$ is a free-by-Demushkin group. 
\end{theorem}

as $G$ is a Bloch-Kato pro-$p$ group.
Consequently, $C$ is a free pro-$p$ group (cf. \cite[Prop.~3.5.17]{nsw:cohm}).
Let $N\subseteq G$ be the normal closure of $C$ in $G$, and let $\tilde N\subseteq F$ be the lift of $N$ in $F$.
Since $r\notin \tilde N$, one has $\tilde N\cap R=[\tilde N,R]$, and $N=\tilde N/(\tilde N\cap R)$
is a free pro-$p$ group as well.

Set $\bar G=G/N$.
Since $H^1(N)^{\bar G}\simeq H^1(C)$, the five terms exact sequence induced by the quotient $G/N$
implies that $H^1(\bar G)\simeq V_1$ and that the inflation map $\inf_{G,N}^2\colon H^2(\bar G)\to H^2(G)$
is a monomorphism (cf. \cite[Prop.~1.6.7]{nsw:cohm}).

\end{itemize}
Koszul ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebras of elementary type are related to the Elementary Type conjecture on
maximal pro-$p$ Galois groups stated by I.~Efrat, cf. \cite{efrat:ETC,ido:small}.

The results of Section~\ref{sec:onerel} --- together with Theorem~\ref{thm2} --- have the following consequence.

\begin{coro}\label{coro:fine}
Let $G$ be a finitely generated one-relator pro-$p$ group.
\begin{itemize}
 \item[(i)] If the ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-cohomology ring $H^\bullet(G)$ is a quadratic ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra,
then the graded group algebra ${\mathbb{F}}_p{[\![} G{]\!]}$ is a Koszul ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra of elementary type. 
 \item[(ii)] If $G=G_K(p)$, with $K$ a field contining a root of unity of order $p$,
then the graded group algebra ${\rm gr}_\bullet({\mathbb{F}}_p{[\![} G_K(p){]\!]})$ is a Koszul ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra of elementary type.
\end{itemize}
\end{coro}

In \cite[Question~2]{MQRTW} it is conjectured that the graded group ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra of $G_K(p)$
is a Koszul ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-algebra of elementary type for every field $K$ containing a root of unity of order $p$
with $G_K(p)$ finitely generated.
Thus, Corollary~\ref{coro:fine} provides new evidence to this conjecture.

 At the end of \cite{wurf}, W\"urfel asked whether every one-relator absolute Galois pro-$p$ group
--- subject to some further cohomological restrictions, as such paper deals with the case where the base field $K$
contains all roots of unity of order a $p$-power --- decomposes as a free pro-$p$ product $G_\circ\ast_{\hat p} F$
of a Demushkin group $G_\circ$ with a finitely generated free pro-$p$ group $F$.
In fact, for $G=G_\circ\ast_{\hat p} F$ one has

Such pro-$p$ group satisfies all the conditions in W\"urfel's theorem (cf. \cite[Thm.~2]{kz}),
and also Proposition~\ref{lemma:onerel}.
In particular, one has $H^\bullet(G)=H^\bullet(\bar G)\sqcap H^\bullet(C)$, with $C=\langle x_3\rangle$
and $\bar G=G/N\simeq{\mathbb{Z}}_p^2$, with $N$ the normal closure of $C$, and 
${\rm gr}_\bullet({\mathbb{F}}_p{[\![} G{]\!]})\simeq{\mathbb{F}}_p[X_1,X_2]\sqcup{\mathbb{F}}_p[X_3]$.
Yet, the group $G$ is not realizable as maximal pro-$p$ Galois group of any field
(see also \cite[\S~5]{ido:small} and \cite[\S~4.2.1]{cq:thesis}).
\end{example}

It is worth observing that by Corollary~\ref{coro:wurfel} free-by-Demushkin pro-$p$ groups ``behave'' like such free pro-$p$ products 
in terms of ${\mathbb{F}}_p$-cohomology and restricted Lie algebras, i.e., the algebras $H^\bullet(G)$ and ${\rm gr}_\bullet({\mathbb{F}}_p{[\![} G{]\!]})$
cannot ``distinguish'' between such free pro-$p$ products and other free-by-Demushkin groups

\begin{example}\label{ex:KZ}
 In \cite{kz}, D.~Kochloukova and P.~Zalesskii produced the following example of free-by-Demushkin pro-$p$ group
which is not such a free pro-$p$ product: let $G$ be the pro-$p$ group with minimal presentation
